Use MySQL Administrator / Restore / Open Backup File to import
bookwarrior.updated*.sql database dump.

Creating a mirror of the Library Genesis


The Library Genesis has three main components:
1) book repository (book files)
2) MySQL database (book records)
3) Web-server (dynamic Web-pages to link the book records and book files, this is the libgen PHP source-code)

As of writing this, there are just over 320,000 books in the Library Genesis repository. The book repository is broken up into directories of a 1000 books each. The name of each book is actually the MD5-hash of the file contents. This allows for robust querying and helps avoid duplicate entries. The MySQL database links book records with book in the repository. The Web-server hosts the PHP-files that request a book info from the database and serve it to the user.

I. Download the libgen book repository.

This is the easiest as well as the most time consuming process, as the repository is 2.5 TB!
Going at 1.0MB/s, it would take a full month to completely download. Fortunately, the Library
can function while incomplete!

You will need a bittorrent client (e.g. utorrent for Windows or Transmission for Linux and Mac) and a RAR archive handler (e.g. 7-zip for Windows or unrar for Linux).

If you do not have the unrar package on Ubuntu, you can install it easily:

Code:
$ sudo apt-get install unrar


Then download the most recent .torrent archive of the repository from http://free-books.dontexist.com/repository_torrent/ .
This file will have a name like 0-276.rar, meaning it has the torrents for the approximately 276000 books. Each .torrent file
contains just one of the 1000-book directories. You can unpack this .rar:

Code:
$ unrar x 0-276.rar


Then open up Transmission and start downloading every torrent.

That's pretty much it for obtaining the repository. You may need more space, or to divide the repository up over multiple directories or hard drives. That's more than okay; libgen is robust enough to handle this.

II. Install the MySQL database

If you have not previously installed MySQL, you need to do that now.

Code:
$ sudo apt-get install mysql-server


During installation, you will be asked to provide a password for the database's root user. Write this down as you will need it later.

Make sure your MySQL server is running:

Code:
$ /sbin/service mysqld start


And then you can issue commands to mysql using

Code:
$ sudo mysql


Enter the following into the mysql prompt:

Code:
CREATE USER 'bookuser'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'bookpass';
GRANT USAGE ON * . * TO 'bookuser'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'bookpass' WITH MAX_QUERIES_PER_HOUR 0 MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_HOUR 0 MAX_UPDATES_PER_HOUR 0 MAX_USER_CONNECTIONS 0 ;
GRANT SELECT , LOCK TABLES ON `bookwarrior` . * TO 'bookuser'@'localhost';


You can then exit mysql with
Code:
exit

After this, make sure you have downloaded the most recent MySQL database dump from your preferred libgen mirror (e.g. http://dl.dropbox.com/u/3268251/backup-last.rar).
Extract the .sql file and save it to your machine under a name you can remember (e.g. dump.sql).

To set up the database:
Code:
$ mysql -p -u root < dump.sql


You will be prompted for your mysql password, and then your database should be set up.

III. Get the webcode up and running

First, make sure you have apache2 and php5 installed. Ubuntu comes with apache2 by default, but not php5.

Code:
$ sudo apt-get install php5


Restart apache2 after installing php5.

Code:
$ sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 restart


Now download the source code for the website, again from your favorite mirror. (I use http://assembla.com/spaces/libgen ).

Unpack it into a directory in your apache2 site directory (default /var/www). I use /var/www/libgen.

Open up config.php and make the following edits:

Code:
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ // mysql params
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ $dbhost = 'localhost';
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ $db = 'bookwarrior';
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ $dbtable = 'updated';
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ $dbuser = 'root';
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ $dbpass = 'My_pass_here'; // <-- Put your own MySQL password here


Scroll down and make sure repository also points to the right place:

Code:
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ $repository = array(
åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ åÊ '0-300000' => '/path/to/libgen'); // <-- Put path to your libgen repository here.


Last, but not least, create a file called index.php. It's contents should simply be:

Code:
<?php
åÊ åÊ header('Location:search.php');
åÊ åÊ die();
?>


And then just load up your web browser and navigatee to yourdomain.com/libgen/

And bam, there it is.

IV. Things that can go wrong
A few things can go wrong:
1) If you can get to the site but see nothing at all (blank page), it probably means you forgot to restart apache2 after installing php5.
2) If you don't have access to the site, your problem is probably with apache2 settings or web server settings. Try navigating to the site using http://127.0.0.1/libgen/. If you can get the site like this, but not through the Internet, make sure your network permissions are set up correctly.
3) If you try to download a book and get a File not found error, your apache2 probably can't access your books. Make sure apache has read access to all the books. You can do this by going to your repository directory and typing
Code:
chmod -R 755 *

4) A host of other things. Post on the forums if you have questions. They're really helpful there.

The manual has grown from this topic.

The truth is that I'm not too familiar with the software myself. I'm a physicist, not a computer programmer. The purpose of this guide was to allow other people like me (who may not know much about Linux) create a mirror of the library genesis. I also made it so people who do not speak Russian (like me) can install the library. All the other resources on this site are in Russian and it becomes difficult to get everything right if you don't speak the language. If there is enough interest I can translate it into Spanish, Swedish, or Turkish.

I do not know how to handle queries with PostgreSQL or sqlite, as I've only ever used mysql for my own programming. As a consequence, this guide only uses mysql. I would love it if someone could post the equivalent commands for me, and I will update the guide with those.

Certain parts are very straightforward though. If you use a webserver that is not apache5, then you follow the same instructions but use a different default location for your web files.

okmijn22 wrote:

Further information: I am using backup-lar.rar which is 300mb and the specific file specified from the instruction which is a--2012-02-25-T-11-37-bookwarrior.rar which is 239mb
it seems to be the problem with backup script, we handled this problem ones (Bill_G, did we??), but somehow it's probably there again. Sorry for that. When the manual was being written, I was backing the DB up from MySQL Administrator, from where it does everything very nicely. From command line it should always work fine. The reason of such failure is that MySQL Admin seems to create some sort of check sum and inserts it in commentaries, then it checks it when you use its GUI to restore from the dump. But the DB info outside the commented section is exactly the same.

So the fix would be to use mysql directly:
Code:
mysql -u root -p < dump.sql
-p will make it ask MySQL root's password.

Try and tell me, if it worked out for you.

Cheers.

yes, it is inauthentic The primary contributors are Russian speakers (many are not Russians though), and it is historical that it's been kept so, no special effort was made to make it non-English or non-Chinese...

Quote:
PS. If this is of interest to anyone, it seems Bibliotik is coming back!
well, that's good. Otherwise it's been looking like some sort of mass execution...

Could there then be a specific section for English or Chinese speakers in the forum because it seems we are getting off-topic, and that I have some other problems that do not pertain to be addressed here.

no, there is not. We are a very small community, it makes no sense to split it by the language criterion. English speakers, as you can see, are more an exception. It's just recently that quite a number of guys leaked from LNU to us, but normally English vibes aren't heard here often.

i've been trying to organize it in a better way, but it never comes out better. It is the complexity of the project and the degree of involvement that members have, that doesn't let it fragment into better defined topical sections. It's OK, if you post anywhere, if confused. We are not moderation nazis here, everything is well though of before actions taken. If the place is wrong, one of the moderators will move it to where it fits better. In other words, the circle of people is quite close and we do not tend to act too formally, dragging everyone through heavy policy chapters etc. Just keep it adequate that the others can see your point, that's it.

Please, if your question is about a specific book, post the corresponding URL so that we can fix the problem. // bookwarrior

Thanks a lot.

the book is there, don't worry: the uploader is hosted on one of our servers, the books are manually redistributed over mirrors later. It is unscheduled and not automated. You can see the book straight away after the uploading in http://free-books.us.to/ search results. The other mirrors are normally delayed by a few weeks or so.

As for the forgotten record fields, just find your book in the search (free-books...), click link "Edit" (access genesis:upload) and modify the data as appropriate.

Welcome btw.

Thanks, I didn't know there was another website. I also fixed the metadata of the other post.

I'll report here if I have any other questions.

Best

Hi, I was a regular at gigapedia, and uploaded several books, and also here at LG. I was taught how to scan a book from a tutorial "make_djvu_with_scantailor"...

However I do not know how to scan a book with lots of color illustrations, say every page is colored. If I try the tiff/scantailor/djvusolo scheme the file gets really huge.
I have seen very good scans of 1000 colored pages books in a single 30mb djvu file.
How can I do this?

Thanks

The only way I know to do this is to use the didjvu encoder, but it‰Ûªs a command line program available only on Linux as far as I know.

It separates the images into foreground, background and mask (bicolor) layers, so for instance if the background is white and the text is black and red, the background will be white, the mask will contain all the text in black, and the foreground will contain the text with colors, the DjVu file won‰Ûªt be much larger than if it were bicolor, and you can OCR it because there is a bicolor mask. You can view the different layers with DjView (and also WinDjview and MacDjview I guess).

Example for one page:
Code:
didjvu encode --lossy -m otsu -o file.djvu file.pnm
This uses the ‰ÛÏotsu‰Û algorithm to separate the background and foreground of file.pnm to create file.djvu.

If there are pictures (and not just colored titles or graphics) there will probably be a visible loss of quality (even without the --lossy option), and if the contrast between foreground and background is not sufficient (for instance, red text on a black background) it can fail to properly separate the foreground and the background, so when you use it you really have to test the different algorithms (there are 9 of them and depending of the type of image you are encoding it‰Ûªs not always the same that will perform best), to check the quality of the result for each page, and adapt the options if necessary.
It can help to transform the images before encoding them with didjvu, for instance by increasing the contrast, or by applying white- and black-thresholds to them to make the background white and the text black rather than gray.

Didjvu can also create bundled djvu documents (with didjvu bundle), but personally when I create a djvu of a colored book, I have a directory with the pages to encode (in pnm format), I create a directory named djvu, and I create one djvu file per page (with for loops) in the djvu directory, this way I can encode all the bicolor pages with minidjvu, and all the grayscale/color pages with didjvu (or c44 if I can‰Ûªt adjust the options to get a good result with didjvu), and I choose the best options for each page (or rather each type of page: bicolor, or with a colored title, or with dark text on a light background, or with pictures‰Û_). Then I use djvm to create the final file.

Part of the problem with the size of the program solves Scan Tailor, for processing raw scanned pages.

lillab wrote:
The only way I know to do this is to use the didjvu encoder, but it‰Ûªs a command line program available only on Linux as far as I know.

It separates the images into foreground, background and mask (bicolor) layers, so for instance if the background is white and the text is black and red, the background will be white, the mask will contain all the text in black, and the foreground will contain the text with colors, the DjVu file won‰Ûªt be much larger than if it were bicolor, and you can OCR it because there is a bicolor mask. You can view the different layers with DjView (and also WinDjview and MacDjview I guess).

Example for one page:
Code:
didjvu encode --lossy -m otsu -o file.djvu file.pnm
This uses the ‰ÛÏotsu‰Û algorithm to separate the background and foreground of file.pnm to create file.djvu.

If there are pictures (and not just colored titles or graphics) there will probably be a visible loss of quality (even without the --lossy option), and if the contrast between foreground and background is not sufficient (for instance, red text on a black background) it can fail to properly separate the foreground and the background, so when you use it you really have to test the different algorithms (there are 9 of them and depending of the type of image you are encoding it‰Ûªs not always the same that will perform best), to check the quality of the result for each page, and adapt the options if necessary.
It can help to transform the images before encoding them with didjvu, for instance by increasing the contrast, or by applying white- and black-thresholds to them to make the background white and the text black rather than gray.

Didjvu can also create bundled djvu documents (with didjvu bundle), but personally when I create a djvu of a colored book, I have a directory with the pages to encode (in pnm format), I create a directory named djvu, and I create one djvu file per page (with for loops) in the djvu directory, this way I can encode all the bicolor pages with minidjvu, and all the grayscale/color pages with didjvu (or c44 if I can‰Ûªt adjust the options to get a good result with didjvu), and I choose the best options for each page (or rather each type of page: bicolor, or with a colored title, or with dark text on a light background, or with pictures‰Û_). Then I use djvm to create the final file.

Meanwhile I found out about djvu_imager: http://www.djvu-soft.narod.ru/scan/djvu_imager.htm
This should be similar to what you describe, but I think it works on windows. I will try this method in the next days.

Also, I went back I tried again. If I scan at color tiff 300, then output from scantailor at mixed 600, and then use djvusolo (or djvusmall) with the encoding Scanned 300, it actually gives a reasonable quality and size (about 200 kb for a full size color illustration). It's not photo quality both for textbook illustrations it's mostly enough.

For manual segmentation (separation of images and text from ScanTailor output along with DjVu encoding), you may want to use my https://github.com/ashipunov/img2djvu
I use it extensively under Linux, and it normally works better than didjvu and Djvu Imager.

Just a New Year's Thanks

I just want to thank the staff for providing this valuable service. There are many of us who need to learn but don't have a lot of funds. I have ten bucks left in the bank after rent and food. But I'll hope for a better new year and donate when I can.

And yet, like many here I am sure, I donated a couple of years to serving others - in my case with a national website that helped the disabled fight a crooked insurance company.

So although we are not all vastly rewarded for our work, as are crooked bankers, we do good, and at least we get to learn so we can fight another day ;')

So thanks again, and a good New Year.

I split off this topic for the reason that many people feel like giving a positive feedback and struggle looking for the right place. Here will be the one. We enjoy seeing it too, even though there is nothing much to respond, we do appreciate your attitude and most of all that LG makes your educational progress faster: it is the most difficult intellectual path of all you could have choosen and the unavailability/inaccessibility of literature can cease you from performing at the limit of your abilities. We are happy that with LG you feel like a speedy man on this road




It is even more important that you absorb the culture of free sharing, apt at academia, but departing further and further away from it. When your education is over, you will be carrying this memory in you and convey to future generations that knowledge must be free and there must be a place somewhere with the books awaiting your curiosity. Free availability should kill the sick monetary attitude to knowledge sooner or later.

Thanks for greetings, Merry Xmas to you too and good luck with your project!

thank you Karl Marx

You are very welcome, I mean in a broad sense, as a "truth seeker" in a way. Feel free to duplicate your messages or keep them in English, because English-to-Russian translation works much better than the other way around, because our language structurally is a lot more complex, also, to avoid a double translation in case we wish to clarify some lexical points etc.

It's really pleasure (very rarely occuring in the World!) when people express opinions like yours. I myself have been travelling for about ten years in different countries and continents and saw/heard myself just what you have said. It is even harder to see, if you are not Russian, because even for us the things are not so clear before we leave the country and live somewhere for a while observing how it all happens in the World, watching different TV channels, absorbing information from different sources. It is truly so that the US channels are extremely narrowly filtered for "simple people", effectively doing anything they want. Russia, unlike the US, provides both views and thus it cannot be worse in giving out the information.

Hello and thank you!

idontspeakrussian
no worries, you'll live long enough to have the Russian language learnt

as for the contributions, especially if you have 300k downloaded, the first-priority-contribution would be to create a mirror, yes. We can help out on choosing an abuse tolerant hoster, you'll waste a lot of time in blind leaps otherwise, don't believe hoster's ads "warez etc is OK", it's almost always a lie or full of conditions that make the whole thing useless. If no Web, you can still share in your LAN among colleagues or friends, faculty, school, institute, lab etc. All is OK. But of course, the best help is when the collection keeps spreading further so that you serve as a channel rather than a terminal leaf.

More words on what can be done can be found here.

Hello,

First, I want to say thank you to all of you (and Internet) who make it possible for us (around the world) to have a chance to open our world.

I remember my last year at university, I have to stay all night to download an article (working paper) for my dissertation. But now, I (and many my compatriot) have a huge library in my house, and on my desk.

In Vietnam we don't have many libraries, and library don't have many books. Thank to all of you (gigapedia, library.nu, avaxhome, etc), we have a change stand on shoulders of giants now.

A new lunar year is coming, I want to borrow two calligraphy of Master Thich Nhat Hanh to wish you a happy new year!

Hello Friends,
I am happy to be here and see some old friends
Bests Regards
I like this forum, amazing and very informative,

I'd like to join the chorus in praising what you've done here.

Many thanks!

Without it, I wouldn't have finished my PhD, or at least, my dissertation wouldn't have been as strong and varied. Although our university library is well-equipped, some of the books were only available via interlibrary loan, which takes time, and you can only keep the book for so long (in which case you just end up photocopying the whole thing anyway). And, of course, there is always something to be said for 'having' the book, in the sense that you can search and consult it whenever a new thought strikes you.

I'm now an instructor at a university, and I see the insanity of copyright restrictions, access fees, reproduction rights... I was going to have my students get a print course reader with a varied selection of texts via one of those academic course package services, until I got word of the cost: $150 per student, and 80% of the price was merely to cover copyright and reproduction. The majority of students have it hard: tuition is already sky-high - I'm speaking here from Canada, which is better compared with the US, but still, university is more and more becoming a zone for the elite, and I'm not referring to an intellectual elite, alas.
Not wanting to throw my students deeper into the cycle of permanent debt, and remembering my own financial stuggles (well, I'm still burdened by student debt, but luckily I made it through with some scholarships) I decided on a compromise: a cheap print reader, and scanned texts distributed through Blackboard.

Anyhow, all this rambling is just a convoluted way of me saying thank you! It's good to see 'free' (in all senses of the word) zones in the corporatization/commodification of knowledge...

thanks you for your words, we deeply appreciate your attitude!

I'd just like to express my thanks to LG for providing the invaluable service of making so much knowledge available to the rest of humanity. I was a heavy user of Library.nu when it was around and it was thanks to Library.Nu that I was able to complete my thesis and much of my education before then. It was therefore especially devastating when LNU was taken down last year. I work in a semi-academic position now and while LNU is gone, I am glad to see that LG is around to carry the good fight. I now use LG for whenever I have need of a book.

Once again, many thanks for the great service you are doing for humanity and more power to you.
